DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the status of the EGFR amplification.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The EGFR gene at chromosome 7p12.3-p12.1 encodes the EGFreceptor, a cell surface transmembrane protein tyrosine kinase involved in regulation of cell growth and differentiation. The gene is not expressed in mitotically quiescent cells, except in the stomach where it controls the synthesis and release of digestive enzymes and gastric acid. EGFR tyrosine kinase activity is required for internalization or degradation of EGF-EGFR receptor complexes. EGFR signaling involves small RHO GTPases and EGFR trafficking involves small RAB GTPases._This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The EGFR gene at chromosome 7p12.3-p12.1 encodes the EGFreceptor, a cell surface transmembrane protein tyrosine kinase involved in regulation of cell growth and differentiation. The gene is not expressed in mitotically quiescent cells, except in the stomach where it controls the synthesis and release of digestive enzymes and gastric acid. EGFR tyrosine kinase activity is required for internalization or degradation of EGF-EGFR receptor complexes. EGFR signaling involves small RHO GTPases and EGFR trafficking involves small RAB GTPases.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in the epidermal growth factor signal transduction pathway.

Property.preferredDefinition: Selective replication of DNA sequence within a cell, producing multiple extra copies of that sequence.

Concepts.definition: This technique refers to selectively replicate DNA sequence of interest to multiple extra copies that meet the need of research or health care activity. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), can be considered a type of man-made gene amplification process.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: A functional unit of heredity which occupies a specific position (locus) on a particular chromosome, is capable of reproducing itself exactly at each cell division, and directs the formation of a protein or other product. The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A cellular process characterized by the production of multiple copies of a particular gene or genes in the genome._A condition or state at a particular time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The non-affirmative response to a question.: A cellular process characterized by the production of multiple copies of a particular gene or genes in the genome.

Concepts.definition: The non-affirmative response to a question.
Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the gain of one or more copies of a DNA segment that contains at least one gene.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A cellular process characterized by the production of multiple copies of a particular gene or genes in the genome.

Concepts.definition: Any DNA sequence rearrangement that results in the gain of one or more copies of a DNA segment that contains at least one gene.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Indicates that an assessment was not performed.

The gene as a functional unit consists of a discrete segment of a giant DNA molecule containing the purine (adenine and guanine) and pyrimidine (cytosine and thymine) bases in the ordered and correct sequence that encodes a specific functional product (i.e., a protein or RNA molecule).
